awd_titl_txt: Conference: Microlocal Analysis and Spectral Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Microlocal Analysis and Spectral Theory" that will be held on October 12-13, 2019 at University of California-Berkeley.
 
The conference focuses on recent developments in analysis, especially in the fields of microlocal analysis.   A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference.  This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference.   The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities.   More information will be made available at: https://math.berkeley.edu/~zworski/rbmconf.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The grant supported two major conferences:

1) Microlocal Analysis and Spectral Theory

A Conference in Honor of Richard Melrose

which took place at UC Berkeley October 19-20, 2019

Microlocal Analysis uses the methods motivated by classical/quantum correspondence (particle/wave correspondence) in partial differential equations. Spectral theory has its origins in analysis of light spectra (used, for instance, to tell the composition of stars) but has become omnipresent in science (for instance for the study of stability). Not surprisingly, considering its physical origins, microlocal methods have been powerful in unlocking the mysteries of spectra of differential operators. The topics covered during conference included spectral theory of quantum graphs, quantum chaos, internal waves in fluids and spectral geometry. Richard Melrose has been a leading force in the development of microlocal analysis and in the training of its current practitioners in the US (a decision was made not to have any of his students speak but two of his mathematical ``grandchildred" did).

2) Harmonic Analysis and Waves,

a Conference Celebrating Hart Smith

which tool place at Univ of Washington Aug 10-12, 2022

Harmonic analysis has its origins in representation of signals as superposition of simpler waves. One mathematical description of harmonic analysis is as
a loosely defined field centered around
Euclidean group structure, the Fourier transform,
and an array of analytic inequalities for functions and linear operators. It is closely related to microlocal analysis which in some sense is the L2 harmonic analysis (square integrable functions describing wave functions of quantum mechanics) combined with symplectic geometry (mathematical framework for classical mechanics).  Both are crucial in the mathematical study of wave phenomena and such aplications were the focus of this meeting. The topics covered included wave equations of general relativity, fine spectral asymptotics taking into account the underlying classical dynamics, dispersive equations, internal waves in fluids and maximal function estimates. Hart Smith has contributed to the field in many significant ways and that was reflected in the scientific content of the talks.

Both conferences had distinguished lists of speakers and were attended by a diverse group of researchers, including a large number of young researchers and graduate students.
